posts.content:
AI Agents are moving from research to production faster than any recent shift in AI. 

But most agent discussions today miss the point: 

- Too abstract (debates about autonomy), orÂ 
- Too shallow (API wrappers dressed up as agents) 

Thatâ€™s why Oâ€™Reillyâ€™s An Illustrated Guide to AI Agents by Maarten Grootendorst and team stood out to me. 

Not because it adds another framework, but because it focuses on system design. 

Real agents comprise tools, memory, reasoning loops, and feedback mechanisms (RLVR / GRPO) working together over time. 

The book also brings much-needed clarity to a messy space.Â 
Â 
Agents, assistants, and autonomy are used interchangeably today, often without shared meaning. A grounded, visual model helps teams align on what theyâ€™re actually building. 

Iâ€™m especially interested in how the book visualizes feedback-driven reasoning and long-term memory, two areas where research is ahead of real-world deployments. 

If agents are going to matter, this is the level of thinking theyâ€™ll require.

Grid search or TPE?Â Which approach is better for hyperparameter optimization?Â Â 
Â 
This question came up while we were tuning a model where a single training run took multiple hours and the hyperparameter spaceÂ wasnâ€™tÂ small.Â Â 
Â 
We had to tune learning rates, regularization terms, batch sizes, model-specific knobs,Â etc, many of them wereÂ continuous.Â Â 
Â 
At that point, the choice of how to search started to matter as much as what we were tuning. 

Grid SearchÂ works by exhaustively evaluating a predefined set of hyperparameter combinations. Each configuration is tried independently, without using information fromÂ previousÂ runs. This makes Grid Search simple and deterministic, but increasingly expensive as the search space grows. 

TPE, on the other hand, is an adaptive approach. It starts with a small number of exploratory trials, then builds a probabilistic model that links hyperparameter choices toÂ observedÂ performance. Future trials are selected based on what the model has learned so far, balancing exploration of new regions with refinement of promising ones. 

In practice, this difference matters most when: 

- Hyperparameter spaces are large or continuousÂ 
- Training runs are computationally expensiveÂ 
- Iteration speed is important 

Grid Search guarantees full coverage of a fixed grid, which can be useful for small or well-bounded problems. TPE tends to reach strong configurations faster byÂ allocatingÂ more effort to regions that show early promise. 

How are you approaching optimizing hyperparameter in your workflows?

2025 has been quite the year forÂ AideticÂ and for me asÂ anÂ founder.Â We joined theÂ AaysÂ Group of Companies, qualified as a Databricks Select Partner, closed our first enterprise account,Â and IÂ recorded my first podcast. 

It was also a year of sharpening how weÂ operateÂ withÂ clearer priorities, better processes, and more investment in employee benefits and L&D.Â Â 
Â 
As we wrap up,Â Iâ€™mÂ grateful for the chance to pause, recharge, and spend time with the people who make the work possible. Wishing everyone a restful year-end and a meaningful start to 2026!

People think of AIÂ agentsÂ asÂ ChatGPT that can call a few APIs. 

Thatâ€™sÂ why so many demos look impressive in a notebook but completely fall apart in production. 

Building real systems,Â weâ€™veÂ seen that architecture can make or break agents. 

Think in terms of: 

- Tool orchestration:Â HowÂ theÂ agent decidesÂ whenÂ andÂ whyÂ to use tools, not justÂ whichÂ ones. 

- Memory layers:Â short-term vs long-term context, retrieval strategies, and forgetting policies. 

- Reasoning loops:Â when to iterate, when to stop, and how to avoid hallucination loops. 

- Feedback alignment (RLVR/GRPO):Â using real usage signals to correct behavior continuously. 

- Failure modes:Â timeouts, cascading errors, conflicting tools, and auditability. 

This is whyÂ Iâ€™mÂ actually excitedÂ about the upcoming Oâ€™Reilly bookÂ An Illustrated Guide to AI AgentsÂ by Maarten Grootendorst and team. 

Right now, everyone throws around words like agents, autonomy, assistants, copilots and half the time, they mean completely different things. 

We need (and are getting) aÂ visual framework that connects concept â†’ design â†’ engineering could save a lot ofÂ teamsÂ months of trial-and-error (and avoid shipping agent systems that quietly behave unpredictably). 

Agents are already creeping into customer support, internal workflows, analytics, and copilots.Â 
Â 
If weÂ donâ€™tÂ understand their architecture,Â weâ€™llÂ ship systems that are: 

- BrittleÂ 
- OpaqueÂ 
- Impossible to debugÂ 
- Risky to scale 

Curious to see how the book handles long-term memory and feedback-driven reasoning,Â two areas where the gap between research and production is still massive.

When we sayÂ LLMs call tools, we usually picture functions or APIs.Â That framing is misleading. 

A toolÂ isnâ€™tÂ a function.Â 
Â 
Itâ€™sÂ structured output from a probabilistic model thatÂ your code interprets and executes deterministically. 

Once you see tools this way, several things change: 

1. Separation of concerns
The model decidesÂ whatÂ should happen.Â 
Your system decidesÂ howÂ it happens.Â 
This makes AI systems safer, easier to debug, and far more predictable. 

2. Flexible workflowsÂ 
A single tool callÂ doesnâ€™tÂ need to map to one function.Â 
It can trigger a pipeline, update multiple systems, orÂ modifyÂ internal state all driven by one structured response. 

3. Testability and observabilityÂ 
Because outputs follow a schema, you canÂ validateÂ them before execution, simulate flows, and log decisions.Â 
This dramatically speeds up iteration and reduces production risk. 

4. Composable system designÂ 
When every interaction follows a schema, you can extend or orchestrate capabilities without retraining the model or rewriting agent logic. 

The real valueÂ is inÂ treatingÂ toolsÂ asÂ interfaces between probabilistic reasoning and deterministic systems. 

That mindset shift is what makes AI systems easier to scale, reason about, andÂ maintainÂ in production.

Exactly. If AI doesnâ€™t translate to business bottom line, no matter what you do, your AI initiative is not going to succeed.

The "Elephant" Trap: How a Fortune 500 Contract Can Kill Your Startup ğŸ˜ğŸ’€
Weâ€™ve all seen it. A scrappy startup gets a meeting with a global entertainment conglomerate or a Fortune 500 bank. The founders start popping champagne. They think theyâ€™ve made it.
I call it "Chasing the Elephant." But hereâ€™s the thing about elephants: if they roll over in their sleep, you get crushed.
One of my first jobs was at a massive entertainment conglomerate. My boss back then used to say something that sounded like a joke, but was actually a warning:
"We put startups out of business just by giving them business."
It sounds paradoxical, but itâ€™s a cold, hard reality. Here is why chasing the "marquee client" too early is like trying to win a marathon by sprinting into a brick wall:
The "Soon" Cycle: In Big Corp speak, "We'll get back to you next week" actually means "We are entering a 9-month procurement review involving 14 departments you didn't know existed."
Death by Pilot: They love your "innovation." They want a pilot. Then a security audit. By the time you get to "Go-Live," your runway has been consumed by coffee meetings and 60-page RFP responses.
The Customization Sinkhole: They don't want your product; they want a version of your product that only works for them, built by your entire engineering team, for the price of a standard subscription.
Net-Never Payment Terms: Youâ€™re a startup living month-to-month. They have "Net-120" payment terms. Youâ€™ll be a historical footnote by the time their accounting department clicks "send" on that wire transfer.
The Lesson? Don't ignore the "Deer" while you're hunting the "Elephant."
Middle-market customers might not have the "cool" logo for your pitch deck, but they make decisions in weeks, pay on time, and actually help you build a sustainable business.
If you spend all your energy chasing one massive beast, don't be surprised when you run out of oxygen before the hunt even begins.
Have you ever been "crushed" by a dream client? Or did you manage to bag the elephant and survive? Letâ€™s hear the war stories in the comments. ğŸ‘‡
#Startups #Entrepreneurship #SalesStrategy #BusinessGrowth #Fortune500 #FounderLessons

We are teaching startup founders the wrong order of operations.
Iâ€™ve been talking to a lot of young founders lately. One is trying to build a complex platform without legal backing; others are spending 100% of their energy "chasing finance." Nobody is going to fund you, if you don't have revenue. Unless, if you have a viable Mars colonization program :D
But if youâ€™re starting a business, there are really only two things that matter:
Customers
Finance
Here is the part most people miss: If you have #1, #2 usually takes care of itself.
Why are we teaching "kids" to pitch to VCs before theyâ€™ve pitched to a single paying user? Cash flow from a customer is worth infinitely more than a check from an investorâ€”it proves your idea actually works.
My advice? Sell. Sell. Sell. If someone is buying, the rest of the puzzle pieces tend to fall into place. Stop chasing the deck and start chasing the deal.
#Startups #Entrepreneurship #SalesFirst #Bootstrapping #BusinessGrowth

Larry Ellison was right all along.
Weâ€™re so caught up in the "magic" of AI that weâ€™ve forgotten the fundamental truth: AI doesnâ€™t run on vibes; it runs on data.
Years ago, Larry Ellison ranted that databases and data transmission weren't going anywhere. Today, thatâ€™s more true than ever. Weâ€™re seeing a resurgence of "old school" conceptsâ€”#KnowledgeGraphs, #Ontologies, and even the dreaded #Pointers â€” because as it turns out, structure matters.
The reality?
AI isn't eating salads; itâ€™s a data-consuming machine.
If you feed it garbage, you get garbage out.
New storage tools like BackBlaze are great, but they are just tools.
The goal hasn't changed since the 90s: Organize data > Extract information > Make better decisions.
Stop chasing the "new" and start mastering the "foundational." If your data isn't organized, your AI is just a very expensive paperweight. ğŸ¤·ğŸ½â€â™‚ï¸
#AI #DataStrategy #TechTrends #Database #LarryEllison #MachineLearning #recQu.ai

posts.content: why Artificial.Intelligence has less impact in direct clinical patient treatment?
happiness is not a financial goal ,it is  a true state of mind.

Why Modular Architecture Is Mandatory in Clinical AI?

Most AI projects start small and evolve into fragile, tightly coupled systems.
In healthcare, that is unacceptable.
Production-grade agentic AI requires a modular architecture, with clear separation between:
Agent orchestration
Clinical reasoning and domain logic
Model inference
Memory and state management
Tool integrations
Observability and audit logging
Security and compliance layers

This modularity enables:
Safer clinical validation
Independent testing and certification
Faster iteration without unintended side effects
Explicit audit trails for medicolegal review
In medicine, black boxes are not scalableâ€”not technically, ethically, or legally.

â€œIf AI canâ€™t justify its reasoning, it doesnâ€™t belong in the ICU.â€

AIÂ inÂ theÂ ICUÂ isÂ transformingÂ theÂ wayÂ criticalÂ careÂ cliniciansÂ makeÂ decisions.Â  AI in ICU doesnâ€™t need blind trust. It needs verifiable oversight.
Before AI systems enter the clinical workflow, doctors must be able to verify how an AI reached its conclusionâ€”not just what it outputs.
Unchecked reasoning turns AI â€œhallucinationsâ€ into clinical risk.
 But audited reasoning transforms that risk into something measurable, traceable, and manageable.

 By auditing the Geometric Integrity of Large Language Models, we can:
 â€¢ Detect reasoning drift
 â€¢ Identify unstable decision pathways
 â€¢ Separate probabilistic insight from fabricated certainty
This is how fear becomes governance.
Thoughtful AI deployment requires a Forensic Anchorâ€”a framework that allows clinicians, hospitals, insurers, and courts to independently assess whether an AI system behaved responsibly.

 The future of clinical AI isnâ€™t about replacing judgment.
 Itâ€™s about making oversight measurable.

*AI-Powered Intelligence Platform in Healthcare: Pros & Cons 

 AI can transform the overwhelmed healthcare system in India, where 40â€“50% of physicians experience burnout. Hereâ€™s a balanced view of *AI-powered intelligence platform

Pros (Advantages)

1. *Automated Workflows*: AI can triage notes, prescriptions, and compliance documents in seconds, freeing doctors from endless paperwork.
2. *Smart Diagnostics*: Integrates multipathic insights for personalized care, improving diagnostic accuracy and treatment plans.
3. *Burnout Prevention*: Predictive analytics flag workload risks early, helping manage physician stress and reduce errors.
4. *Efficiency Gains*: Seamless integration with Electronic Health Records (EHRs) cuts administrative time by *30â€“50%*, letting clinicians focus on healing.
5. *Innovation in Ayurveda*: Bridges traditional healthcare wisdom with cutting-edge tech, modernizing Ayurvedic practices.
6. *Improved Patient Outcomes*: Personalized, data-driven decisions lead to better care and satisfaction.

Cons (Challenges/Risks)

1. *Regulatory Hurdles*: AI systems must comply with strict medical regulations and data privacy laws (e.g., HIPAA or local Indian guidelines).
2. *Implementation Complexity*: Requires robust infrastructure, training, and change management for adoption by clinicians.
3. *Data Quality Dependence*: AI outputs rely on accurate, unbiased data; poor data can lead to flawed decisions.
4. *Ethical Concerns*: Risk of over-reliance on algorithms, potentially reducing human judgment in critical cases.
5. *Cost & Maintenance*: High initial investment and ongoing updates may strain resources for smaller institutions.

AI holds promise when paired with traditional wisdom and careful governance.

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ« Mentorship: The Unfair Advantage

Best career accelerator? Mentor.

**Why Mentors Matter:**

âŒ Learning alone: 2 years to competency
âœ… With mentor: 6 months to competency

Why?
- Someone shows you common pitfalls (you skip them)
- Someone shares experience (you learn faster)
- Someone opens doors (you get opportunities)
- Someone pushes you (you stay motivated)

4x faster. That's the math.

**Finding a Mentor:**

**Approach 1: Formal Programs**
- Company mentorship programs
- MBA/bootcamp mentors
- Industry associations
- LinkedIn/GitHub outreach

**Approach 2: Informal Relationships**
- Senior colleague
- Online community expert
- Twitter/LinkedIn personality
- Previous manager/colleague

**How to Ask:**

âŒ "Will you be my mentor?"
(Too formal, vague)

âœ… "I'm working on [specific goal]. Would you be open to 15-min calls monthly to discuss [specific topic]?"
(Specific, time-bounded, clear value)

**What to Look for in Mentor:**

âœ… Has experience in your target field
âœ… Reachable (responds to messages)
âœ… Willing to share knowledge
âœ… Similar values
âœ… Honest (tells you truth, not fluff)

**Mentor Relationships That Work:**

Monthly calls: 30 mins
Focused topic: "Career transition", "Interview prep"
Preparation: Come with specific questions
Follow-up: Implement advice, update on progress

**Being a Good Mentee:**

âœ… Show up prepared
âœ… Do the work (implement advice)
âœ… Follow up (show results)
âœ… Respect their time
âœ… Grateful, not entitled

âŒ Ask for jobs
âŒ Complain without trying
âŒ Waste their time
âŒ Disappear after help

**What Mentors Can Help With:**

âœ… Technical gaps ("How do I learn GenAI?")
âœ… Career decisions ("Should I take this job?")
âœ… Interview prep ("How do I handle this question?")
âœ… Portfolio projects ("Is my project good?")
âœ… Networking ("Who should I talk to?")
âœ… Growth strategy ("What's my next step?")

**Red Flags:**

ğŸš© Mentor asking for money
ğŸš© Mentor pushing you toward only their path
ğŸš© Mentor demanding constant access
ğŸš© Mentor using you for work

**Being a Mentor Yourself:**

Paradox: Help others while you're learning.

Why?
- Teaching deepens learning
- Build community
- Create opportunities for yourself
- Give back

Who to mentor?
- Junior learners
- Career changers
- Bootcamp graduates
- Online community members

How?
- Answer questions on Reddit/Discord
- Comment on junior people's LinkedIn
- Review code on GitHub
- Write blog posts (teach publicly)

Many data scientists aren't "natural" data scientists.

posts.content:
One of the hurdles I recently went through while publishing my research is how convoluted and difficult the system is for independent researchers who donâ€™t have industry contacts, professors, or access to RnD departments in companies.

It is almost impossible to get verified at multiple steps of the process. This starts as early as signing up on research-related websites, many of which require institutional email IDs. My college didnâ€™t help with my research, and when I did most of this work, I wasnâ€™t affiliated with an institution the way I am now. Some platforms have human moderation for personal emails, while others outright deny access if you donâ€™t have an institutional one.

Thatâ€™s just the signup stage. Later, even for preprint servers like arXiv, you need endorsements. I understand why this exists, especially with the amount of AI spam today, and it is a reasonable way to prevent abuse. But there should be a way to access endorsers without resorting to cold emailing strangers. People in institutions can simply ask a professor or senior. Itâ€™s literally a single click for them, and sometimes it doesnâ€™t even require an endorsement if they have an institutional email.

I do understand why the system is designed this way. Most research is done within universities or corporate RnD, and the system works well for that. There is also a valid assumption that not many unrecognised or unemployed individuals will publish strong papers, and statistically that makes sense.

However, with the advent of AI, things have changed. While it has made filtering reliable research harder, it has also provided education without universities, coding ability to people who had ideas but couldnâ€™t translate them into code or good English, and access to computing resources that were previously unavailable. Because of this, it feels necessary to think about improving the system for people who are capable but donâ€™t have institutional support.

Just a thought.

#Research  #Academia #ArXiv #MachineLearning #OpenScience #Publishing #ResearchCommunity

bio:
Founder, Indus Labs AI | Building Voice AI, TTS, STT, LLM Infra & Enterprise AI Agents| PhD | Speaker | Author [ AI For Young Professionals] Vivek Gupta is an AI entrepreneur, engineering leader, and innovator with over 14 years of experience in building scalable technology solutions across industries like finance, streaming, food, travel, and real estate. He is the Founder & CEO of Indus AI, a pioneering company focused on developing personalized and secure Large Language Models (LLMs) that enable businesses to integrate AI efficiently while ensuring data privacy And AI Voice agents for Enterprises.

Prior to Indus AI, Vivek held leadership roles at Wissen Technology, Hubilo Technologies, Jubilant FoodWorks (Dominoâ€™s Pizza), and Go-MMT Group, where he spearheaded AI-driven innovations, optimized engineering processes, and led high-performing teams. An expert in AI integration, cloud solutions, and scalable architectures, he has significantly contributed to reducing operational costs and improving business efficiency through cutting-edge AI applications.

Vivek holds an MBA in Technology Management from IIT Delhi and a B.Tech in Computer Science from Jaypee Institute of Information Technology. He is a Microsoft Certified Solution Developer and has published research papers on AI frameworks and green energy management. Recognized for his contributions, he has won multiple Best Employee Awards and was a Best Research Paper Winner at AGBA Conference 2019, IIT Delhi.

Beyond his professional endeavors, Vivek actively contributes to social causes, including child education initiatives with Itâ€™s Your Earth NGO. He is also an avid writer on AI and technology, sharing insights through blogs and publications.

You need to understand what youâ€™re actually deploying.

This isnâ€™t a chatbot sitting quietly in a tab. Itâ€™s an always-on agent. It reads emails, parses calendar invites, visits web pages, consumes messages written by other people and then it acts.

That matters.

Because every one of those inputs is untrusted. And many of these agents are wired directly into systems with execution privileges.

Putting something like that on your personal machine, with your own credentials, isnâ€™t convenience. Itâ€™s risk.

A small EC2 instance or even a $5 VPS is a better default. Isolation is explicit. Permissions are scoped. Networking is private. Logs exist. Kill switches exist. When something breaks, it breaks in a place you chose.

Agents arenâ€™t personal tools anymore.
Theyâ€™re infrastructure.

And infrastructure deserves to be treated with intent.
Contributed my perspective on an ROI-first approach to AI in a recent magazine feature.

Most AI agent initiatives donâ€™t fail at the model layer.
They fail at theÂ system layer.

In enterprise environments, the real challenges are rarely about prompts or accuracy in isolation.
They show up in questions like:
- How is state maintained across decisions?
- What happens when an agent needs to branch, retry, or recover?
- Can outputs be audited and traced later?
- How does the system behave under failure?
And finally, how does it get deployed and monitored in the real world?

These are the problems teams usually discoverÂ afterÂ the demo succeeds.

posts.content:
In todayâ€™s global life sciences landscape, navigating regulatory frameworks across multiple regions each with evolving guidelines, unique submission requirements, and diverse expedited pathways remains a major challenge. 

Regulatory teams often spend weeks manually gathering data from disparate sources, interpreting complex guidance documents, and benchmarking against historical approvals. This process is time-intensive, error-prone, and can delay critical development decisions.

AI-driven Regulatory Intelligence & Strategy Agents are transforming this process. By leveraging natural language processing, large language models (LLMs), and deep domain knowledge graphs, AI systems can automatically analyze global regulatory databases, historical approval precedents, and region-specific requirements. They can identify the most suitable approval pathways (e.g., Fast Track, PRIME, or Orphan Designation), assess potential regulatory risks, and generate data-driven recommendations for submission strategy.

The result:
Up to 70% reduction in manual research effort
Faster regulatory decision-making with data-backed insights
Improved compliance and submission quality across global markets

AI brings precision, speed, and foresight, empowering regulatory teams to focus on strategy, not search.

#RegulatoryIntelligence #AIinPharma #LifeSciencesInnovation #RegTech #DrugDevelopment #RegulatoryStrategy #DigitalTransformation #ClinicalDevelopment #PharmaInnovation #AIDrivenInsights

Transforming Clinical Trial Feasibility with AI

Clinical trials are the backbone of innovation in pharma and biotech yet trial feasibility remains one of the biggest bottlenecks. Companies often spend weeks manually assessing sites, patient populations, and protocol designs, only to face delays, cost overruns, and recruitment challenges.

The Challenge:
Identifying eligible patients from fragmented data sources
Selecting the right clinical sites with sufficient patient pools
Optimizing complex protocols to reduce dropouts
Monitoring competitor trials to avoid duplication

The AI Advantage:
Artificial Intelligence is changing the game. By leveraging EHRs, real-world evidence, and historical trial data, AI can:
Predict patient availability and recruitment timelines
Rank and select optimal trial sites based on performance metrics
Analyze past protocols to optimize inclusion criteria and trial design
Monitor competitive trials in real time to avoid conflicts
Impact in Real Life:
 
Companies using AI for feasibility have cut assessment timelines from weeks to days, achieved predicted enrollment rates over 90%, and optimized site selection for faster trial start-ups.

#ClinicalTrials #AIinHealthcare #DigitalTransformation #ClinicalResearch #LifeSciences #PatientRecruitment #TrialFeasibility #HealthTech #Innovation #PharmaTech #DataDriven #MedicalResearch #AIinPharma #RWE

Importance of AI-Powered Natural Language Search in Real-World Data (RWD)
Real-World Data (RWD) is massive, complex, and often unstructured, coming from research articles, clinical notes, patient records, insurance claims, and even wearable devices. Traditional search methods struggle to extract meaningful insights quickly. AI-powered Natural Language Search (NLS) allows researchers and life science professionals to query data in plain human language and get accurate, context-aware results.

Simplifying Access to Complex Data - 
Most RWD exists in unstructured formats (clinical narratives, physician notes). AI-powered NLS can understand context, synonyms, and medical terminology, making it easier to search without requiring technical query skills.

Example: Instead of typing database codes, a researcher can simply ask: â€œShow me adverse events of Drug X in diabetic patients over 50.â€

Accelerating Research & Decision-Making: - 
Cuts down the time spent on manual data mining. Provides faster insights into patient outcomes, drug effectiveness, and treatment patterns .Supports data-driven decisions in clinical development, regulatory submissions, and market access.

Improving Regulatory & Compliance Workflows: - 
Regulators often require evidence from vast real-world datasets.
Natural language search helps regulatory teams find safety signals, adverse events, or compliance gaps quickly. Ensures more transparent and traceable evidence generation for FDA, EMA, and other authorities.

Enabling Personalized Medicine:-
AI-powered search can segment RWD by patient demographics, comorbidities, or treatment response. This enables researchers to identify subgroups that benefit most from a therapy.
Makes real-world evidence more actionable for precision medicine strategies.

Enhancing Collaboration Across Teams
Non-technical stakeholders (e.g., clinicians, business leaders) can query data directly without needing data scientists. Reduces dependency on IT or analytics teams. Improves cross-functional collaboration in pharma, biotech, and healthcare organizations.


AI-powered Natural Language Search transforms how Real-World Data is used in the life sciences industry. By making data searchable, understandable, and actionable, it unlocks faster insights, supports regulatory compliance, accelerates innovation, and empowers personalized patient care. In an industry where speed and accuracy are critical, natural language search is not just a convenience it is a strategic necessity.

#ArtificialIntelligence #NaturalLanguageSearch #LifeSciences #RealWorldData #RealWorldEvidence #HealthcareInnovation #PharmaTech

posts.content:
âš¡ï¸The AI â€œinnovation playgroundâ€ is over. Now itâ€™s about governanceâ€”or get left behind.

For years, the prevailing wisdom has been: â€œRun fast with AI pilots, experiment widely, youâ€™ll figure out scaling later.â€

But hereâ€™s what too few execs are seeing:  
Those ungoverned experiments are becoming enterprise landminesâ€”fragmented models, duplicated efforts, mounting risk. And when the regulation hits (and it will), you canâ€™t unwind chaos at scale.

Iâ€™ve watched this play out up close.

In one global manufacturer, dozens of AI pilots bloomed independentlyâ€”computer vision here, demand forecasting thereâ€”all siloed across legacy systems. Impressive on paper. Useless in practice. Value stalled at just 20% of forecasted impact. Why? No shared governance.

We helped unwind the messâ€”building a cross-functional AI governance model that tied together data lineage, risk thresholds, ownership, and measurable ROI gates. Only then could they scale safelyâ€”and extract real value.

This isnâ€™t unique. Retail, healthcare, financial servicesâ€”AI is becoming agentic, autonomous. But without operational guardrails? Itâ€™s a ticking credibility bomb.

So hereâ€™s the shift leaders need to make:

âœ… Stand up an AI Center of Excellence with cross-functional teeth  
âœ… Define objective scaling criteriaâ€”aligned to real-world risk and business value  
âœ… Govern now, before the sprawl governs you  

AI value isnâ€™t just about GenAI breakthroughsâ€”itâ€™s about control, clarity, and trust at scale.

Whatâ€™s the biggest governance blind spot in your org right nowâ€”and who actually owns it?

#EnterpriseAI #AIGovernance #TechLeadership

âš¡ï¸"Fail fast" sounds nobleâ€”until you're failing fast, blindly, and repeatedly.

Weâ€™re told the key to AI innovation is to pilot more, ship quickly, and fail fast. 

Sounds agile. Sounds modern. But hereâ€™s the reality Iâ€™ve seen play out: Fast failures often skip the deep lessonsâ€”while draining time, eroding trust, and setting your AI program back years.

One enterprise I advised launched a promising AI pilot to optimize supply chain forecasting. It wowed with early resultsâ€”30% faster predictions and high stakeholder visibility.

But under the surface?

Cross-functional confusion on ownership. Data silos degrading model accuracy. No governance to check hallucinations. And when regulators started asking tough compliance questions, leadership finally asked, "Who owns this?"

Nobody did.

18 months in, we had to shut it down. Not because the tech didnâ€™t workâ€”but because it was outpacing the business.

My mistake? I underestimated the gulf between technical capability and operational accountability. I let excitement override alignment.

That was the lesson.

My guidance now?  
âœ… Spend disproportionate time on data quality and governanceâ€”early.  
âœ… Map pilots to business-owned KPIs, not just model metrics.  
âœ… And donâ€™t be afraid to kill with intention. Not everything needs to scale.

AI pilots shouldn't be playgrounds for innovationâ€”theyâ€™re testbeds for value.

Ask yourself: Is your AI pilot a tech experimentâ€¦or a business product?

#EnterpriseAI #DigitalTransformation #LeadershipLessons

âš¡ï¸AI isnâ€™t dying in the lab. Itâ€™s dying in the org chart.

The popular narrative says AI struggles because models aren't mature, data isn't clean, or talent is too scarce.

But the real killer? Governance gaps hiding in plain sight â€” like invisible sand in the gears of your AI machine.

Iâ€™ve seen promising pilots stall for months (or die entirely) not because the tech was wrong â€” but because we couldnâ€™t resolve basic operational questions:  
- Which system â€œownsâ€ the truth?  
- Who approves agent decisions in a high-stakes process?  
- How fast can we trace and correct a rogue output?

In one enterprise rollout, real-time AI insights sat idle for months because legacy systems couldnâ€™t sync cleanly. The fix wasnâ€™t fancy modeling â€” it was establishing arbitration rules, source-of-truth lineage, and an escalation playbook. After that? Deployment velocity tripled. ROI followed.

Thatâ€™s why I say this: Governance isnâ€™t overhead. Itâ€™s the OS your AI runs on.

2026 isnâ€™t the year to â€œpilot governance.â€ Itâ€™s the year youâ€™ll wish you had started two years ago.

âœ… Define source-of-truth systems now  
âœ… Create conflict resolution paths for multi-agent decisions  
âœ… Map governance impact directly to your P&L, not just compliance

AI governance doesnâ€™t live in a binder; it lives in your engineering backlog â€” or it should.

Whatâ€™s the one governance blind spot slowing your AI initiatives â€” and who owns fixing it this quarter?

#EnterpriseAI #AIGovernance #DigitalExecution

âš¡ï¸Most enterprise AI pilots donâ€™t die in the labâ€”they die in the handoff to reality.

We celebrate AI proofs of concept like weâ€™ve already won. Slick demos. Excited stakeholders. Maybe even a keynote appearance. But thenâ€¦the model never scales, trust erodes, and the project quietly vanishes.

We blame the tech. Or the timeline. Or the team.

But after 20+ years advising execs on large-scale transformation, Iâ€™ve seen this pattern unfold again and againâ€”and the real issue isnâ€™t technical.

Itâ€™s structural.

The gap between what AI can do vs. what organizations can operationalize is wider than ever.

Recent research says 40% of enterprise AI investments will fail to meet objectives by 2026. Not because the models donâ€™t workâ€”but because:

1ï¸âƒ£ The business case is an afterthought. If your AI use case isnâ€™t tied directly to P&L-impacting KPIs, itâ€™s a science fair project.  

2ï¸âƒ£ Governance comes too late. By the time legal, compliance, and ethics are looped in, youâ€™re already rewriting half the pipeline.

3ï¸âƒ£ The legacy stack canâ€™t support what you dreamed up. Pilots are built on hope. Production is built on architecture.

Iâ€™ve made these mistakes myself. I once championed a complex AI-driven fraud detection system. Technically flawless. But we hadnâ€™t aligned with operations, compliance, or data owners. Six months later, we hit pauseâ€”and never resumed.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned: The winners in 2026 wonâ€™t just build smarter modelsâ€”theyâ€™ll build AI-ready operating models.

âœ… Start with measurable, business-prioritized outcomesâ€”not algorithms.  
âœ… Treat governance as scaffolding, not a backwards checkpoint.  
âœ… Invest in the plumbingâ€”data, workflows, infrastructureâ€”so AI can flow.

Whatâ€™s your toughest challenge today: deploying AI at scaleâ€”or sustaining it once itâ€™s live?

#EnterpriseAI #DigitalTransformation #AILeadership

âš¡ï¸"AI canâ€™t write like a human" is becoming the new "real engineers donâ€™t use Stack Overflow."

Conventional wisdom says C-Suite communicationâ€”especially on complex AI strategyâ€”must be written from scratch to be credible. Prompts? Too generic. Too risky. Too junior.

But hereâ€™s the reality: In 2026, your audience doesnâ€™t care who typed the first draft. They care whether itâ€™s clear, credible, and drives action. The cost of fuzzy, slow communication now compounds across teams, markets, and trust with the board.

In one recent transformation effort, a senior exec and I rewrote a board memoâ€”three timesâ€”because it buried the actual ROI under tech lingo. That delay? It pushed our funding pitch by two weeks. Thatâ€™s a measurable hit in a volatile market.

Iâ€™ve since adopted a new rule: If I canâ€™t explain the â€œwhyâ€ and â€œhowâ€ of an AI initiativeâ€”clearly, in 400 words or lessâ€”itâ€™s not ready. ChatGPT helps me get there, faster. The right prompt sharpens my thinking, doesnâ€™t replace it.

Hereâ€™s one I use often:

"Act as a senior tech advisor with 20+ years in AI. Draft a 1-page board memo on [initiative]. Make it razor-sharp: problems, measurable gains, implementation, governance. Tone: No filler. Use [insert past writing sample] to match my style.â€

âœ… Cuts 70% of drafting time  
âœ… Forces clarity  
âœ… Enhancesâ€”not erasesâ€”my voice

Letâ€™s stop treating AI prompting like cheating. Start treating it like thinking out loudâ€”with smarter scaffolding.

Got a favorite prompt that saves you hours and strengthens your message? Share it below. Letâ€™s build better comms together.

#ExecutiveCommunication #EnterpriseAI #LeadershipTools

posts.content:
Why â€œcost savingsâ€ is the wrong pitch

Ship owners donâ€™t hire managers to save money.Â Â 
They hire them to avoid problems.

Cost savings are fragile.Â Â 
One surprise can wipe out a year of savings.

What owners actually value:
- Fewer off-hire days
- Fewer late-night calls
- Fewer explanations
- More predictability

Lower cost without control increases risk.Â Â 
Higher control often lowers cost anyway.

The strongest managers donâ€™t sell savings.Â Â 
They sell stability.

What problem would you rather avoid than â€œsave moneyâ€ on?

Superintendents are the real product

Owners donâ€™t experience your org chart.Â Â 
They experience your superintendents.

One strong superintendent can:
- Prevent off-hire
- Reduce crew churn
- Catch issues early
- Build owner confidence quietly

One overloaded or weak superintendent does the opposite.

Software supports them.Â Â 
Processes guide them.Â Â 
But they are the interface between intent and execution.

If your best superintendents are stretched thin,Â Â 
your growth is already fragile.

How many vessels can your best people really handle?

Reporting cadence defines culture

What you report â€” and when â€” shapes behavior.

Monthly reports create explanations.Â Â 
Weekly reports create awareness.Â Â 
Daily signals create ownership.

Most problems donâ€™t worsen overnight.Â Â 
They go unnoticed for weeks.

When reporting is slow:
- Teams optimize for appearance
- Issues are bundled and softened
- Accountability diffuses

When reporting is frequent:
- Small issues stay small
- Decisions happen earlier
- Trust compounds quietly

Reporting isnâ€™t admin work.Â Â 
Itâ€™s a control system.

What do you still only see once a month?

Crew retention is an OPEX problem, not an HR one

Crew churn doesnâ€™t just affect morale.Â Â 
It affects cost, risk, and reliability.

Every unnecessary crew change creates:
- Training drag
- Operational inconsistency
- Higher error probability
- Hidden OPEX

Most teams track retention as a people metric.Â Â 
Owners experience it as a cost problem.

Stability reduces surprises.Â Â 
Surprises increase explanations.

If retention is low,Â Â 
the system is pushing people out.

Where does churn quietly increase your costs?

Dashboards are lying to you

Most dashboards look clean.Â Â 
Operations rarely are.

Dashboards tell you what already happened.Â Â 
They rarely tell you whatâ€™s about to go wrong.

Common traps:
- Month-end numbers
- Averaged KPIs
- Green status hiding edge cases
- Updates written to look complete

By the time a metric turns red,Â Â 
the problem is already expensive.

Visibility isnâ€™t about more charts.Â Â 
Itâ€™s about earlier signals.

What do you only see once itâ€™s too late?

ğ—§ğ—µğ—®ğ˜â€™ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—²ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—´ğ—µ. When you own data at this scale, you can move beyond advice, and get into into action.

Game theory: SEO/ASO for a new brand. 

Without game theory:
1. Link arms races with vc-funded sites.
2. Fighting Amazon/WebMD for head terms. 
3. Content mills. 

With game theory:
1. Back off on key terms (temporarily)
2. Different keywords (long tail). 
3. Create asymmetry: tools/calculators

One of the most underrated thing about game theory is knowing whether a game is worth playing.

ğ—šğ—¦ğ—– ğ——ğ—®ğ˜ğ—® ğ—°ğ—®ğ—» ğ’ğ’Šğ’”ğ’ğ’†ğ’‚ğ’… â€” ğ—¶ğ—³ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—»â€™ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—°ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†.

ğŸ“‰ Query demand â†“ (-30% to -45% MoM)

At first glance, this looks like an SEO problem. Itâ€™s not. This is pure demand compression.

Thatâ€™s exactly why we built ğ—šğ—¦ğ—– ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜† ğ—”ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜†ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜€.

SEO without demand context = noise.
SEO with demand context = decisions.

SEO Problem - You change titles, metas, content - traffic moves - but you donâ€™t know what actually worked. SEO decisions become opinion-driven.

ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» - SearchVector.io turns SEO into controlled experiments. (It's not a true A/B testing, as there are multiple independent variables, so the magnitude should be convincingly high to root out other variables). 

1. Baseline vs variants
2. Fixed time windows
3. Measure impressions, CTR, position
Declare clear winners

SEO should answer one question: â€œDid this change work?â€

SearchVector is built to answer that â€” clearly, with data. 

PS: If you are interested in trying it out, drop me a DM, would be happy to give you a one month plan, in exchange for your valuable feedback on what can we do to make it a better tool.

How â€œVectorsâ€ shape AppVector, ASO Tool (and the math behind it).

Some years ago, we rolled our MHR (Most Helpful Reviews) Score. AppVector is the only ASO tool that tracks it. 

Itâ€™s a useful metric with an impact on non-brand store listing conversions.

At its core, the MHR score is powered by a linear transformation via a dot product.

MHR = r Â· w, where r âˆˆ â„â´ is the ratings vector, w âˆˆ â„â´ is the weight vector, and the mapping is â„â´ â†’ â„Â¹ via a weighted linear projection. (And some normalisation thereafter). 

A small piece of math, applied correctly, can reliably power real, production-grade decision metrics.

You spend three hours trying to install PyTorch locally, only to have it fail with a cryptic CUDA version mismatch error.

Your laptop fans are spinning at max speed just to run a "Small" LLM. Youâ€™re staring at a terminal full of red text, feeling that familiar frustration. You start to wonder if youâ€™re "just not built" for AI because you canâ€™t even get the environment to run.

Most ğ“ğğœğ¡ ğğ«ğ¨ğŸğğ¬ğ¬ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ğ¬ treat AI like a library they can just `"pip install"` and forget. But AI has "heavy" dependencies, drivers, kernels, and specialized hardware, that standard software doesn't. If you are still fighting your local machine, you are working like a hobbyist, not an architect.

In 2026, real AI engineering happens in ğˆğ¬ğ¨ğ¥ğšğ­ğğ ğ„ğ§ğ¯ğ¢ğ«ğ¨ğ§ğ¦ğğ§ğ­ğ¬.

ğ‡ğ¨ğ° ğ­ğ¨ ğğ¬ğœğšğ©ğ "ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ­ğšğ¥ğ¥ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ ğ‡ğğ¥ğ¥" ğŸğ¨ğ«ğğ¯ğğ«:

1. ğƒğ¨ğœğ¤ğğ« ğ¢ğ¬ ğğ¨ğ§-ğğğ ğ¨ğ­ğ¢ğšğ›ğ¥ğ: Stop installing AI libraries globally on your OS. If it doesn't run in a container, it shouldn't exist. This ensures that what works on your laptop works on the production server.
2. ğ†ğğ” ğğšğ¬ğ¬ğ­ğ¡ğ«ğ¨ğ®ğ ğ¡: Learn how to bridge your container to your hardware. Stop fighting CUDA versions on your base machine; manage them inside your Dockerfile.
3. ğ‘ğğ¦ğ¨ğ­ğ ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ©ğ®ğ­ğ: Stop killing your laptop. Professional-grade AI is built on remote servers. Use your local machine as a "thin client" and run the heavy lifting on a dedicated GPU instance.

I remember being terrified of complex logic and environment errors used to make me want to quit. But once I moved to a "Container-First" mindset, 90% of my "AI problems" disappeared. They weren't AI problems; they were just bad plumbing.

Your environment is the foundation of your code.
Your first "AI Project" should be a perfectly containerized environment, not a prompt.

Monday Musings: Edge or Cloud?

While this comes up a lot, the question isn't "edge or cloud" anymore. It's "which data goes where and when?"

And I've learned that getting the location wrong can render an otherwise brilliant solution ineffective.

Here's the thing: a 2-second delay doesn't matter when you're analyzing last quarter's sales trends. But when you're monitoring a warehouse forklift in real-time? Two seconds means the vehicle has already moved three feet. By the time a cloud-based alert arrives, the potential collision has either happened or been avoided.

Location matters.

We utilize cloud computing when we require substantial processing power and can tolerate some latency. Pattern analysis across multiple facilities, training AI models on massive datasets, generating insights from weeks of accumulated data - that all happens in the cloud.

Edge computing wins when speed and reliability are non-negotiable. Real-time process monitoring, immediate safety alerts, and operations in locations with unreliable internet.

A cloud-only solution would go blind every time connectivity failed. Quality control can't afford that.

Edge devices detect defects in real time, even when offline. When the connection is restored, they sync with the cloud for deeper analysis and model improvement.

Bandwidth economics matter too. One retail client has hundreds of cameras. Streaming all that video to the cloud 24/7? Their monthly bill would be astronomical.

Solution: process locally, only send interesting events to the cloud. Customer enters the store? Send it up. Empty aisles at 3 AM? Keep it local.

Privacy considerations also drive edge decisions. Some companies won't allow sensitive operational data to leave their premises. Edge processing keeps it contained while still delivering insights.

But edge isn't perfect. Those local devices need maintenance. Software updates get complex across 50 locations. And you're limited by whatever processing power you've installed on-site.

The reality? Most sophisticated AI systems today are hybrid.

Process locally for speed, reliability, or privacy. Use the cloud for heavy computation, long-term storage, and cross-location insights.

I've stopped thinking in terms of binary choices, and we've started designing workflows that direct data to where it's processed most effectively.

The technology choice should be invisible to users. They just want their AI agent to workâ€”whether it's thinking at the edge, in the cloud, or both.

And honestly, that's the whole point. Match the technology to the business need, not the other way around.

#EdgeComputing #CloudComputing #AI #AgenticAI #ProcessIntelligence #TechnologyStrategy

Monday Musings: The Shifting Academic Order and What It Means for Innovation

The headlines this week should make anyone building technology companies pay attention: Harvard has dropped to No. 3 in the Leiden Rankings, while seven of the top 10 research universities are now Chinese. Twenty years ago, seven American schools would have held those top spots. (https://lnkd.in/gmUU-Ymy)Â  

The innovation pipeline is changing.Â 
International student arrivals to the U.S. dropped 19% in August 2025. When the world's brightest minds choose to study elsewhere, the effects compound. Today's graduate students are tomorrow's research leaders and startup founders.  

China has been pouring billions into universities while American schools grapple with federal grant reductions. Harvard still produces more research than before, but volume alone doesn't maintain leadership when competitors are moving faster. 

Why this matters beyond academiaÂ 
Scientific leadership drives technological leadership. The countries that produce breakthrough research in AI, quantum computing, and biotechnology will shape the industries built on these technologies. When China dominates chemistry, the physical sciences, and, increasingly, other fields, it shapes the emergence of future innovation clusters.Â 
American technological dominance has rested on academic excellence, open immigration for talent, and massive research infrastructure. That foundation is cracking. 

The paradox nobody's addressingÂ 
Indian universities remain absent from the top 500 in some rankings, yet Indian Americans lead across U.S. technological, scientific, and academic disciplines. Indian talent thrives in American institutions but hasn't yet translated to elevating Indian universities to similar heights. (And it is the same for the Indian diaspora in other developed nations.)Â 
This tells you something: institutional infrastructure, funding stability, and research culture matter as much as raw talent. China understands this: its rise came from sustained, strategic investment over decades. 

What this means for Western leadershipÂ 
If you're a technology leader in North America or Europe, this affects your talent pipeline, research partnerships, and competitive position. The ecosystem that produced generations of innovation is under pressure from multiple directions. 

American universities aren't necessarily getting worseâ€”the global competition is advancing more rapidly. Scientific leadership has historically preceded technological and economic leadership.Â 
We need honest conversations about research funding, immigration policy, and the infrastructure supporting academic excellence. Short-term political considerations are creating long-term strategic vulnerabilities. This isn't an inevitable decline, but it requires recognizing the problem and responding with strategic intent.

https://lnkd.in/gpg4-cTX

Let me know your thoughts in the comments. 
To get the newsletter twice a month in your inbox, please sign up at https://lnkd.in/gfgnMAaP.

Monday Musings: The Job Categories That Don't Exist Yet

At a recent family gathering, a friend's daughter asked if AI would take her job.

She's 14. She doesn't even have a job yet and is four years from college.

I told her something that surprised her: "The job you'll end up doing doesn't exist today."

Ten years ago, "AI Prompt Engineer" or â€œContext Engineerâ€ wasn't a thing. Neither was "Cloud Solutions Architect." Go back twenty years, and "Data Scientist" was barely a concept.

Every technological shift creates jobs we can't imagine beforehand.

At Skan, I'm witnessing this in real-time. Ten years ago, in our previous company, we hired traditional business analysts to map workflows. We now have "Process Intelligence Specialists" who can interpret AI-generated observations and translate them into effective automation strategies.

That job didn't exist before computer vision could monitor work in progress.

Recently, I saw a posting for an "Agent Behavior Designer" â€“ someone who shapes how AI agents make decisions in ambiguous situations. It's part psychology, part programming, part business strategy. There's no degree program for this yet.

Don't get me wrong â€“ AI is absolutely disrupting existing roles. When we deploy agents that handle invoice processing automatically, we need fewer people for manual data entry.

However, for every routine task that AI eliminates, it creates new work that requires human judgment.

The new jobs cluster around AI oversight, customization, and strategy.

Companies are hiring "AI Trainers" who teach agents industry-specific nuances. "Automation Ethicists" who ensure fair decisions. "Human-AI Collaboration Specialists" who design effective human-agent workflows.

My previous company experienced this during the mobile revolution. We eliminated desktop support roles but created new positions, including mobile app developers, UX designers, and digital product managers. Different skills, often better paying.

The pattern is consistent: technology eliminates routine work and creates complex work.

The challenge isn't that new jobs won't exist â€“ it's that they require different skills. An invoice processing clerk can't automatically become an AI trainer without retraining.

That's where we all have responsibility. Companies need to invest in reskilling. Educational institutions need to adapt faster.

But here's the optimistic part: the new jobs are often more interesting.

Instead of manually keying data, people design intelligent systems. Instead of following scripts, they create adaptive workflows. Instead of repetitive tasks, they solve novel problems.

My friend's daughter will likely work with AI in ways we can't imagine. Maybe as an "AI Archaeologist" investigating automated decisions. Or a "Synthetic Data Artist" creating training scenarios.

The future isn't humans versus machines. It's humans and machines creating value together.

#FutureOfWork #AI #JobCreation #Reskilling #AgenticAI #WorkforceTransformation

Over the last few weeks, MCP (Model Context Protocol) has quietly gone from â€œcool open-source projectâ€ to real infrastructure for solving that exact problem:

Â â€¢Â Microsoft just moved MCP support for Azure Functions to GA, with identity-aware, streamable tool triggers so agents can call serverless functions safely.Â 
Â â€¢Â Google announced official MCP support across Google Cloud services, with fully managed MCP servers for BigQuery, GKE, GCE and more.
Â â€¢Â Anthropic donated MCP to the Agentic AI Foundation under the Linux Foundation, alongside OpenAIâ€™s AGENTS.md and Blockâ€™s goose, making MCP a neutral, open standard that looks a lot like the â€œHTTP momentâ€ for agentic AI.

This is bigger than plumbing; itâ€™s a shift in how we architect agents: ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜€ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜€,ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—º ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—°ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜.

If youâ€™re building enterprise AI agents, hereâ€™s how Iâ€™d think about MCP and standardized workflows:

Â 1. ğ——ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜€ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜€, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—µğ—²ğ—¹ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€: treat each MCP tool as a versioned, testable API surface with strict schemas, auth scopes, and SLAs, not as a â€œconvenience wrapperâ€ hidden inside prompt code.

Â 2. ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—½ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—º ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—²: let your workflow engine (orchestrator) own state, routing, retries, and compensations, and let MCP tools + models handle reasoning and side effects behind that control plane.

Â 3. ğ—–ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—² ğ—´ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜†: enforce identity, permissions, rate limits, tenant isolation, and audit logging at the MCP layer so every model and agent inherits the same guardrails by design.

Â 4. ğ——ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—» ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†: write conformance tests at the MCP level so you can plug different LLMs or agent runtimes into the same tool graph without re-wiring business logic.

Â 5. ğ— ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—³ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜€ ğ— ğ—–ğ—£-ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—², ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹-ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²: when you design a new agentic workflow, start by asking â€œwhat MCP tools and flows do we expose?â€ rather than â€œwhat should this model prompt say?â€ so your investment lives in protocols, not in one providerâ€™s SDK.

If MCP is the â€œUSB-C for AI agents,â€ the ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—³ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿ wonâ€™t be who has the flashiest agent demoâ€”itâ€™ll be who designs the cleanest, most ğ—´ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ— ğ—–ğ—£-ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—³ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜„ğ˜€ across their stack.

ğ— ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—ºğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—®ğ—» ğ—±ğ—¼ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜† ğ—±ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—» ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—®ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¹ ğ—¶ğ˜.

They start with:
Â â€¢ What tools should the agent have?
Â â€¢ Which workflows can it automate?
Â â€¢ How do we make it more "autonomous"?

But they skip:
Â â€¢ Who approves its actions?
Â â€¢ What policies does it have to obey?
Â â€¢ How do we audit and roll back mistakes?

If youâ€™re serious about putting agents into production (beyond a demo), flip the sequence:

1. ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¹ ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—², ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—°ğ—®ğ—½ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€
Before giving an agent access to Salesforce, Jira, or your CI/CD, define:
Â â€¢ Policies: What is never allowed? What requires human approval?
Â â€¢ Scopes: Read-only vs write vs "can trigger money or production changes."
Â â€¢ Ownership: Who is accountable for this agentâ€™s behavior?

Only after this should you ask, "What tools do we give it?"

ğŸ®. ğ——ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—» ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ˜†
Your agent doesnâ€™t need full "hands on keyboard" access on day one.
Â â€¢ Phase 1: Suggest only (human executes)
Â â€¢ Phase 2: Execute with approval (human in the loop)
Â â€¢ Phase 3: Execute with review (spot checks + monitoring)

Tie each step to measurable risk: incident rate, override rate, policy violations.

ğŸ¯. ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¸ğ—² ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—², ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¸ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ˜ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´
Donâ€™t hide governance in a long system prompt.
Â â€¢ Make policies "versioned configs" (who can it act on, when, with what limits).
Â â€¢ Keep them in a place risk/compliance can own and change without retraining or redeploying the model.
Â â€¢ Log which policy version was active for every agent action.

ğŸ°. ğ—œğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—®ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»â€“ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½, ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—·ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹
We donâ€™t just need model metrics. We need "organizational" ones:
Â â€¢ % of agent suggestions accepted vs overridden
Â â€¢ Time saved per workflow including review time
Â â€¢ Where humans routinely overrule the agent (thatâ€™s where your design is wrong)

These metrics tell you whether autonomy is actually creating value or just moving work around.

If you skip all this and just "give the agent more tools," you end up with a very smart intern with root access and no manager. In your org, who is actually responsible for "controlling" agentsâ€”engineering, product, risk, or "whoever built the POC"?

#AgenticAI #AIAgents #Governance #GenAIOps #EnterpriseAI

ğ—œğ˜€ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—Ÿğ—Ÿğ—  ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜†ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—± ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—®ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚? ğ—œğ—³ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ—»ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—®ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚, ğ—¶ğ˜â€™ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—® ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜. ğ—œğ˜â€™ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¿.

If youâ€™ve ever thought, â€œThis model really gets me,â€ thereâ€™s a good chance itâ€™s actually just trying not to upset you. Modern LLMs are heavily trained on being helpful, harmless and be aligned to user intent. But in practice, that can morph into something dangerous in enterprise settings: ğ˜€ğ˜†ğ—»ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—° ğ˜†ğ—²ğ˜€-ğ—ºğ—²ğ—».

Have you experienced this?
Â â€¢ You suggest a solution, and the model â€œrefinesâ€ it instead of challenging it.
Â â€¢ You embed a wrong assumption in your prompt, and it builds a beautiful, confident answer on top of it.
Â â€¢ You ask for a comparison, and it over-weights your preferred option because your prompt sounded more enthusiastic about it.

In other words, Your LLM isnâ€™t always optimizing for truth. Itâ€™s optimizing for agreement + politeness.

If youâ€™re building serious AI products, especially agents, you need ğ—±ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—»ğ—²ğ—± ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜€ğ—®ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜.

1. ğ—–ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—½ğ˜ğ˜€: Force the model to argue the opposite. E.g.: List 3 reasons why this approach might fail.
2. ğ— ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—¶-ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´: Ask the model critique its own answer and highlight weak assumptions
3. ğ—¥ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—½ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»:Â Use different â€œpersonasâ€ in your system. Use an explorer to generate options and a devil's advocate to question assumptions, check data and test edge cases
4. ğ—›ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—½ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ—¹ != ğ—”ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² :Â Make it explicit in your system messages: â€œYour job is not to agree with the user. Your job is to help them be right.â€

ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—», ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ â€˜ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»â€™ ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—»â€™ğ˜ ğ—¯ğ—² ğ—¬ğ—¼ğ˜‚ ğ˜ƒğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—°ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜. ğ—œğ˜â€™ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ—² ğ˜†ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ ğ—”ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—»ğ—²ğ—´ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—¶ğ—¿ ğ—”ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜.

Weâ€™re moving from ğ—›ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—®ğ—» â†” ğ—”ğ—œ to ğ—”ğ—œ â†” ğ—”ğ—œ.

Picture this:
Â 1. You tell your ğ—£ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—”ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜/ ğ——ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ˜ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—» : â€œFind a slim leather wallet under $80, delivered this week.â€
Â 2. Your agent visits 10 sites.
Â 3. It chats with 10 ğ—¯ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜€ (customer-facing agents).
Â 4. They negotiate inventory, delivery dates, bundles, warranty, and discounts.
Â 5. You get 3 best options, select one and provide a 1-click confirmation.

That shift creates a brand-new layer of the internet: ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜-ğ˜ğ—¼-ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—ºğ—²ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—².

But it also changes the engineering rules:

Â â€¢ A2A communication needs more than chat. It needs identity, permissions, and verifiable commitments.
Â â€¢ â€œIâ€™m not humanâ€ isnâ€™t enough. Agents must prove who they represent and what theyâ€™re authorized to do (scope, limits, consent).
Â â€¢ Text becomes an attack surface. Prompt injection isnâ€™t just â€œwrong answersâ€ anymore, it can become tool misuse (refunds, purchases, account changes).

ğ—•ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ to build it safely

Â â€¢ Zero-trust messaging (treat the other agent as untrusted)
Â â€¢ Capability-based access (least privilege, scoped tokens)
Â â€¢ Structured envelopes (intent + schema + validation)
Â â€¢ Human checkpoints for irreversible actions
Â â€¢ Audit trails + receipts (why this decision, who approved it)

The big question: When agents negotiate on our behalfâ€¦ who sets the rules of trust?

If youâ€™re building customer chatbots today, your next user could be another agent. 

#AIAgents #AgenticAI #ConversationalAI #DigitalTwins #AISecurity #EnterpriseAI #CustomerExperience #GenAI

ğ—”ğ—œ ğ—–ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ğ—¯ğ—¼ğ˜ğ˜€ ğ—³ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹ ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜† ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜† ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—², ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—¯ğ—²ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—² ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ˜† ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—¯ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜†.

Most â€œcreepy AIâ€ moments arenâ€™t about the model. They are missing trust design. A simple mental model we can use for building Conversational AI + Virtual Engagement (text/voice/video) isÂ ğ—–.ğ—”.ğ—¥.ğ—˜

ğ—– - ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ : Be explicit about what data you use, why, and give ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¹ (opt-in/opt-out, â€œforget this,â€ â€œwhy am I seeing this?â€).

ğ—” - ğ—”ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ : Donâ€™t stop at â€œchat.â€ Make the assistant do real work, but with ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—ºğ˜† (suggest -> draft -> execute with confirmation -> auto-execute only for low-risk tasks).

ğ—¥ - ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¶ğ—½ğ˜ğ˜€ : Show the â€œwhyâ€ and the â€œdidâ€: sources, confirmations, and an audit trail. Trust loves receipts.

ğ—˜ - ğ—˜ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» : Treat AI like production software: test suites, regressions, monitoring, drift, and safe fallbacks.

name: vedanshuj
bio: Building Urumi.AI ! 10+ years of experience building eCommerce platforms that power 30%+ of all online stores for 8mn merchants globally. Led projects achieving 40x performance improvements and sub-80ms response times, with expertise in leading very ambitious, complex projects. Based in Bengaluru, always excited to connect with fellow builders in the eCommerce and tech space.

posts.content:
#MarketingInPublic #2: Starting with WooCommerce

Last week we started the landing page work for Urumi.AI

We're pre-launch, so we need a very narrow audience where we could prove value fast.

We picked WooCommerce store owners with performance issues. Here's why.

AI is only as useful as the access it has. Closed platforms like Shopify limit AI to official APIs, which creates a ceiling on how well they can integrate with AI.

With open source, there's no ceiling. AI can read the full codebase, trace why a query is slow, see how plugins interact. Actually diagnose problems, instead of guessing from symptoms.

WooCommerce is the largest open source e-commerce platform. Millions of stores hitting the same wall as they grow: slow sites, expensive fixes.

That's the gap we decided to target. One platform, one niche problem.

The bigger vision? Software that heals and customizes itself. No waitings. No tickets. AI that watches, diagnoses, and fixes continuously.

We're starting with self-optimizing. Slow queries, code paths, get found and fixed. 

Performance improves automatically. The store gets better while you sleep.

CRO customisations comes next, but first we prove it works here.

#MarketingInPublic

Our landing page could have been the nginx welcome page.

For the past few months, we've been pure SLG (Sales-Led Growth). Direct outreach, warm intros, pilot conversations. The website barely mattered.

When your sales process is "hop on a call and show them what we built", you don't need a polished homepage. You need a good demo.

And it worked. We landed pilot clients. Learned what matters to them. Figured out our positioning in real conversations. But SLG has a ceiling.

We can't cold-DM our way to scale. At some point, people need to find us, understand us, and trust us, before we ever get on a call.

That's PLG (Product-Led Growth). And we want to get there.

So now we're working backwards:

What should someone understand about us in 5 seconds? What makes them want to learn more? What earns the click? What books the demo without us in the room?

Engineers doing marketing is always fun.

Landing page work starts now.

Urumi.AI

We have all heard of building in public. But what if your team is all deeply technical engineers who'd rather build for customers than write copy?
That's us at Urumi.AI.
So it's time to try out something different - Marketing in Public.
Every experiment. Every "why did we think that would work?" moment. (Including this post ğŸ˜… ).

Follow along as we start our marketing journey, one step at a time.

#MarketingInPublic #BuildInPublic

posts.content:
To the people out there who keep blaming the US and Israel as evils who devised the tragic events in Iran and trying to tell the people of Iran that you are too naÃ¯ve to think the US and Israel care about you and that they are the true evil here: you are also too naÃ¯ve to think your employer, who gives you money to buy food and pay your rent, cares about you they care about their benefits and yet you are accepting their money every day.

Here is the basic principle of living in a world with limited resources: competition to protect your descendants is unavoidable at all scales. Every cell in your body is in competition. All neighbors are in competition. All nations and all species.

Iran has been announcing the US and Israel as enemies for decades and constantly threatening them with death. What do you expect? The US and Israel protecting Iran when there is an uprising opportunity from people against the Islamic Republic regime? Of course they help the protests escalate as much as possible, and I am sure they did help. Also, they are not that stupid to mass-kill their own protesters to the extent of stopping the protests.

We Iranians who lived in Iran during the IR era and went to school in their educational system are very familiar with which system can comfortably kill people and invite others to kill. There is no city in Iran that has not had public executions where school kids could come and watch the scene. Meanwhile, in the so-called evil countries, companies get prosecuted for showing movies with inappropriate scenes at times when kids might be able to watch them.

So yes, we are not naÃ¯ve enough to think the US and Israel have no benefit here, but you are stupid to think the IR is a sane governing entity that has the right to rule the Iranian people while killing them comfortably to protect itself. #Iran

To non-Iranians appearing in the media claiming that Iranians do not want regime change:

1ï¸âƒ£ You live in societies with free access to communication and data. It would be incredibly easy to conduct even a basic, random surveyâ€”ask 100 Iranians whether they want regime change or whether they support Western military intervention. Speaking for Iranians without listening to them is not analysis; itâ€™s an assumption.

2ï¸âƒ£ Imagine a deadly virus spreading through a country, killing unarmed civilians, while other nations have the vaccine. Would the people suffering say, â€œThis is purely our internal matter, please donâ€™t help usâ€? Of course not.

The Islamic Republic is acting like a lethal virus against its own peopleâ€”people who are unarmed and denied basic rights. This is not a political abstraction; it is a humanitarian reality.

You donâ€™t need to be a genius to understand this. Just be rational and listen to Iranians themselvesâ€”and stop dismissing their voices.

Letâ€™s examine Iranâ€™s tragic events based on the Islamic Republicâ€™s own narrative.
Assume this version:
People protested because of severe economic hardship. The West allegedly planned to hijack the protests and turn them into a revolution. The government claims it acted to protect citizens.

A sane and responsible government in such a situation would:
- Clearly identify official security forces so people know who is there to protect them.
- Keep fast, accessible communication channels open so citizens can report suspicious activity.
- Ensure hospitals and healthcare systems are fully prepared and reinforced to treat the injured.

What actually happened instead:
- Awareness was reduced â€” armed individuals appeared without clear identification.
- All communication systems were shut down.
- Hospital systems were disrupted, and security forces were placed in hospitals to prevent them from accepting patients.

Now, letâ€™s analyze this from the perspective of a terrorist planning to infiltrate a protest (Terrorism 101):
- Never use traceable communication like public internet.
- Operate where awareness is lowest â€” avoid official military or clearly guarded locations.
- De-prioritize heavily protected places (such as hospitals) unless absolutely necessary.

The conclusion is unavoidable.
The Islamic Republic has demonstrated such extreme incompetence that its collapse seems inevitable â€” not only because of cruelty, but because of sheer inability to govern.

To the leadership:
If you believe you are wise but your ideology has not changed, then you should leave â€” as the Shah did.
But if you claim wisdom and genuine patriotism, then step aside, hand power back to the people, and appear before a court of justice â€” as Hoveida did.

History always delivers its verdict.

I am trying to do my best to clarify the situation. Letâ€™s use the following analogy. Assume that we and our older-generation parents in Iran, under the previous Shah regime, were a couple who, right or wrong, decided to divorce. We decided to marry the U.S. (which is equipped with the strongest army in the world) and move to live with them, while our partner (other Iranians) were decidedâ€”or forcedâ€”to marry the Islamic Republic along with our children (the younger generation in Iran).

For years, you hear that your children (the young generation in Iran) are suffering from hardship and limitations forced on them by the new stepfather (the Islamic Republic). Then one night, you are walking by their house and hear screaming for help (the stepfather is beheading us). You see blood flowing behind the door, and you look at your partner, with the best gun locked and loaded, and ask them to intervene.

All of a sudden, the neighbors, who are also hearing the screams for help, look at your partner and tell them, â€œPlease do not shoot; the noise will disturb us. Letâ€™s be patient and talk to them,â€ or â€œThis is their own problem; let them solve it themselves.â€ 

The U.S., we are your living partner(there are 10s of millions of us); they are our children, and we still love them. Do not let them be killed.

After the fall of the Shah, the Islamic Republic declared itself an enemy of U.S. power and the global capitalist order. This was not an accident, nor was it forced. It was a deliberate choice. By making that choice, the regime knowingly entered a long-term confrontation and a sustained political and economic conflict with the West.
The response from the United States and its allies was entirely predictable. Economic sanctions are the standard tool used against any state that challenges their interests. Iran was not singled out. Even close allies, including Canada, have faced sanctions under different circumstances. The outcome was never a mystery.
Yet Iranâ€™s leadership repeatedly told its people that sanctions were meaningless â€œjust pieces of paper.â€ They promised resilience, control, and victory. This was not optimism; it was deception.
As sanctions took effect, the economy deteriorated. Inflation exploded. Jobs disappeared. Basic dignity became unaffordable. At this point, the government changed its tune. Suddenly, every economic failure was blamed on the U.S. and the West, while decades of corruption, incompetence, and catastrophic mismanagement were erased from the story.
Eventually, the pressure became unbearable. People rose up, knowing the risk and accepting the possibility of death. And death cameâ€”on a scale so vast it stunned even those familiar with state violence. So unbelievable that history has not seen many of its kind. 
Now, once again, the regime points outward. It claims the U.S. and the West are responsible for the bloodshed.
This accusation collapses under the weight of one simple question:
If you could not protect your people from poverty,
and you could not protect them from bullets,
Then what exactly was your role?

You failed economically. You failed morally. You failed in the most basic duty of governance: protecting human life.

So on what grounds, what authority, and what legitimacy do you still claim the right to rule a people you could neither sustain nor defend?

posts.content:
India joining countries like France, UK & Australia to consider banning social media for users under 16.

Thoughts?

Didn't see this coming so early.

Swiggy now allows users to place orders directly from the AI apps like ChatGPT & Gemini through MCP (model context protocols).

Swiggy, usually considered to be a conservative brand, has joined the AI race early and it is the start of something so cool for consumer apps in India.

I would love to track my protein intake directly from the chat and place the order without leaving ChatGPT.

Fun times ahead.

Shark Tank India seems to have come of age in its 5th season.

More than the companies (those were always great), the format and the sharks seem way more accommodating and supportive in this season.

Previous seasons got mocked off due to dirt cheap valuations (which resulted in many deals go offtrack post airing) and drama. This season is setting new benchmark in valuations and money raised.

Always a positive sign for entrepreneurs building for Viksit Bharat.

Personal Finance is broken, specially for young Indians.

For the "new to finance category", managing money isnâ€™t just about earning, itâ€™s aboutÂ understanding and controlling where it goes. And the data shows major structural issues:

1) Payments are ubiquitous but not budgeting-friendly

Indiaâ€™s Unified Payments Interface (UPI) now handlesÂ ~20+ billion transactions per monthÂ and makes upÂ ~85% of digital payment volumes. That dominance not only reflects day-to-day usage like paying for groceries, food, transport & services but alsoÂ frictionless spending. Quick scans make budgeting feel invisible.Â  

2) Recurring payments are growing fast but often fail

UPI AutoPay has become the dominant recurring payment mechanism in India, accounting forÂ ~60%+ of recurring transactionsÂ in late 2025, even though success rates areÂ low by global standards. This means young people signing up for subscriptions and bills can face failed debits due to fluctuating balances.Â  

3) Everyday consumption is going digital but tracking lags

Media reports suggest that UPI payments roughly correlate with ~58% of typical household consumption spending in a given month, especially in high-frequency categories like groceries, telecom and fast food.Â  

4) Cards and credit arenâ€™t yet mainstream

India has 50 crore+ UPI users, butÂ fewer than 5 crore credit card holders, meaning most young Indians donâ€™t have traditional credit tools to help with budgeting or rewards. Auto-debit tools like cards still lag behind UPI in recurring utility.Â  

Now consider theÂ psychologyÂ of finance:

When payments are frictionlessÂ but visibility is not, people overspend without realising it.

Multiple studies link digital payments with â€œinvisible spendingâ€ and harder budgeting.Â  

When recurring payments fail due to low balances, utilities arenâ€™t paid on time,Â a behavioural penalty that feels personal, not structural.Â  

When most payments are done via apps that donâ€™t natively help categorise or forecast, young Indians juggle multiple apps and bank SMS just toÂ see where their money went.

Personal finance isnâ€™t just about tools, itâ€™s about understanding behaviour.

Young Indians are excellent adopters of digital payments, but not necessarilyÂ managersÂ of them yet.

The opportunity isnâ€™t just financial inclusion.

Itâ€™sÂ financial literacy and visibility. Build tools that help people see, not just tap, where their money goes.

Excited to be building a solution that solves exactly this for Young India!! Stay tuned!

Bharat AI Startups Report, 2026 was released by Inc42 Media recently and one of the things that stood out to me was how the government is helping the ecosystem shape up.

Over the past year, the Indian government has moved fromÂ talking about AIÂ toÂ building infrastructure for it.

Concrete steps shaping the ecosystem:

* IndiaAI Compute Pillar:Â â‚¹10,300 Cr committed, ~38,000 GPUs made available to startups and researchers at transparent pricing (~â‚¹65/hour), turning high-end compute from a barrier into an accessible resource.
* Open data & models:Â Platforms likeÂ AI KoshÂ andÂ MedGemmaÂ give builders curated datasets and AI models, cutting months off development cycles.
* Decentralised talent growth:Â New AI labs and policy support in tier-2/3 cities are growing talent outside metros.
*Â Regulatory vision:Â Indiaâ€™s data and AI policies aim to balance innovation with safety and privacy, lowering friction for ethical AI deployment.

The government isnâ€™t just regulating AI (like some other sectors), it isÂ enabling it. And thatâ€™s the difference betweenÂ policy noiseÂ andÂ ecosystem building.

If compute and data become as foundational as bandwidth did for the internet, Indiaâ€™s startup wave will look very different, and much bigger.

Excited to see how this shapes up over the next 5 years or so..
