posts.content:
[Model Evaluation] Why Embeddings Matter?
Embeddings are how models represent meaning numerically.
They power search, retrieval, clustering, recommendations, and similarity checks.
If two things mean the same thing, their embeddings should be close.
Embeddings are the quiet backbone of modern AI systems.

#AIEngineering #ModelEvaluation #Embeddings #VectorSearch #LLMs #AIArchitecture

[Model Evaluation] - Lexical Similarity vs Semantic Similarity
Not all similarity is equal.
Lexical similarity checks surface overlap.
Semantic similarity checks meaning.
â€œLetâ€™s eat, Grandma!â€
vs
â€œLetâ€™s eat Grandma!â€
Lexically similar.
Semantically opposite.
Meaning matters more than overlap.

#AIEngineering #ModelEvaluation #NLP #SemanticSimilarity #LLMs #LanguageModels

[Model Evaluation] When Exact Evaluation Isn't Possible!

Many real-world AI tasks donâ€™t have clean success criteria.
So teams rely on reference-based evaluation, comparing outputs against "ground truth".
This works only as well as the reference data.
Incomplete or wrong references create false confidence.
Evaluation is only as strong as what you compare against.

#AIEngineering #ModelEvaluation #AIEvaluation #LLMs #DataQuality #MLPractices

Why Code Generation Is a Special Case â€“ Model Evaluation

Code generation is one of the few AI tasks with clean evaluation.
Why? Because code can be executed and tested.
This is why benchmarks like HumanEval and MBPP work so well.
Unit tests turn AI output into a yes/no signal.
Execution beats eloquence.
Correctness beats fluency.

#AIEngineering #ModelEvaluation #CodeGeneration #LLMs #SoftwareTesting #DeveloperTools

Functional Correctness Is the Gold Standard

The strongest evaluation metric is functional correctness.
Simple question: did the system succeed?

If AI generates code, does it run?
If it books a reservation, was it actually booked?
If it answers a query, is the answer correct?

If the function fails, the model fails.
No ambiguity.
#AIEngineering #AIEvaluation #SoftwareEngineering #LLMs #AIInProduction #Reliability #SystemDesign #QualityEngineering

posts.content:
I Built a Local AI Chatbot on My Phone with React Native (and it was surprisingly easy)

I recently stumbled upon the RunAnywhere SDKs and decided to try something that sounded difficult on paper: running a Language Model (LLM) locally on my mobile device using React Native.

No API keys, no cloud costs, just raw AI running on the phone's hardware.

The result? It was actually incredibly fun, and I got it working in under 100 lines of logic. Here is my experience building a "SmolLM2" chat app.

Why Run Locally?
Usually, when we build AI apps, we just fetch data from an OpenAI or Anthropic API. But running it locally on the device ("Edge AI") feels like 

Privacy: The data never leaves the phone.

Offline: It works in an airplane or a subway.

Cost: Free. No token usage fees.

The Tech Stack
React Native: For the UI.
@runanywhere/core: The main SDK to manage models.
@runanywhere/llamacpp: The backend to run GGUF models.
SmolLM2-360M: A tiny but mighty model optimized for speed.

The Experience
I tested this using the SmolLM2 360M model. Because the model is small (quantized to Q8), it downloaded quickly and the inference speed on my mobile device was snappy.

Itâ€™s a different feeling knowing that the intelligence you are interacting with is sitting right there in your hand, not in a server farm in Virginia.

Itâ€™s fun, itâ€™s easy, and itâ€™s the future of mobile apps.

#ArtificialIntelligence #MobileDevelopment #ReactNative #EdgeComputing #OnDeviceAI #SoftwareEngineering #OpenSource #TechInnovation #Privacy #LLMs

The Cost of Abstraction: Why PyTorch isn't always the answer.

I recently fine-tuned the GPT-OSS 20B model on a single Tesla T4 (16GB) GPU. To make it fit, I used Unsloth.

The experience highlighted an interesting engineering distinction between Unsloth and standard PyTorch.

The "Standard" Way (PyTorch): PyTorch is built for flexibility. When you run a training loop, it typically executes generic kernels for every operation (Normalizations, Attentions, RoPE embeddings). It creates a computational graph that is easy to debug but often computationally wasteful. It reads and writes to memory frequently, creating fragmentation and overhead.

On a memory-constrained card like a T4, this overhead is fatal. You either run out of VRAM (OOM) or hit stability issues (NaN errors) because the generic kernels aren't optimized for the specific mixed-precision quirks of older hardware.

The "Optimized" Way (Unsloth): Unsloth isn't just a wrapper; it drops down a level. Instead of relying on PyTorch's autograd to figure out the backward pass, they have manually derived the backpropagation math and rewritten the GPU kernels in OpenAI Triton.

By hand-writing these kernels, they "fuse" multiple operations into one. This means:
- Fewer Memory Reads/Writes: The GPU doesn't have to keep fetching data for every tiny step.
- Less VRAM Overhead: Intermediate states that PyTorch would store are never created.
- Manual Stability: They handle the precision math explicitly, preventing the crashes common on T4s.

The Takeaway: PyTorch is amazing because it lets you build anything. Unsloth is interesting because it shows what happens when you optimize specifically for one thing (LLM training).

If you are interested in trying it out, check the Unsloth notebook in the comments. 

#MachineLearning #PyTorch #Unsloth #Engineering #DeepLearning #LLM

Itâ€™s not a billion-parameter model, but the learning was massive.

I just finished building a transformer from scratch in PyTorch.

In a world of massive LLMs, itâ€™s easy to get lost in the hype. But sitting down to write the Self-Attention mechanism and Residual Connections line-by-line taught me more about AI than any API ever could.

The journey:
Starting with random gibberish (Loss: 4.6).
Implementing the Causal Mask so the model couldn't "cheat" by looking at the future.
Training on Shakespeare and watching the model actually start to form words (Loss: 2.5).

It isn't about the size of the model; it's about the depth of the understanding. Every "billion-parameter" giant is just thousands of these small "Lego bricks" stacked together.
Fundamentals first. Always.

Models like GPT-5 and Claude 4.5 excel at describing images, but they struggle with tasks requiring pixel-level precision or structured, verifiable output. They're monolithic inference engines, great for interpretation, limited for production pipelines.

I just read VLM Run's whitepaper on Orion, and it tackles this exact problem with a fundamentally different architecture.

The Core Problem

Traditional VLMs try to handle everything like object detection, OCR, segmentation, and spatial reasoning in a single neural pass. This works for general understanding, but fails when you need:

Exact bounding box coordinates (not approximate descriptions)
Pixel-perfect segmentation masks
Verifiable structured data (JSON schemas, not freeform text)
Multi-step workflows with deterministic intermediate outputs

How Orion Solves This

Orion shifts from a monolithic predictor to a unified visual agent that orchestrates specialized computer vision tools:

1. Tool Delegation Over Learned Weights
Instead of predicting "there are approximately 5 birds," Orion calls a detection model and returns: [{class: "bird", bbox: [0.23, 0.45, 0.12, 0.18], confidence: 0.94}, ...]

2. ReAct-Style Planning + Execution + Reflection

Plan: Decomposes requests using chain-of-thought reasoning, determines tool sequences and data dependencies
Execute: Invokes tools sequentially or in parallel based on constraints
Reflect: Uses a VLM-as-a-Judge to validate outputs against schemas, triggers retries on failures

Example: "Detect license plates and blur them" requires detection â†’ localization â†’ inpainting in sequence, with validation at each step.

3. Structured Output Enforcement

Every tool returns Pydantic-validated JSON with type-safe schemas. Segmentation masks are uint8 arrays with per-instance labels. Detections include normalized xywh bboxes. OCR returns word-level confidence scores.
This isn't optional formatting; it's enforced through the reflection loop.

Architecture Insight

The reflection mechanism is key: when a tool returns malformed data or the output doesn't match the expected schema, the VLM-as-a-Judge identifies the inconsistency and triggers corrective actions before proceeding. This closed-loop control is what enables multi-step workflows to succeed reliably.
